page.title: 02Some Doncaster dialect.
page.content: The speech of people in the area is distinctive. Some examples of local dialect are given here. Sweets are{ {spogs, scoffs}or{spice}and chewing-gum is often called{chewwag}or{chuddy.}A fish and chip shop is a{chip-oyle.} Food which is sticky or stodgy is known as{clarty}food - this word can also be used about, for example, sticky mud.{Clarts}is also a word which means clothes. A{beer-off}is an off-licence. A{bairn}is a baby, a younger brother or sister is usually referred to as {our kid}or{young 'un. Sprogg}means giving birth,{sneck}means a nose and a {tab}is an ear. A{duggie}or{dill(an)}is a stupid person,{neb}means nosey. Truanting is{twagging. Myther}means to fuss, and{spragging}means telling tales. A side-alley is a{ginnel. Snap} means a packed lunch or similar.
